												Let me first start by saying this is a "No, for now", not a "No", as most of the issues I see are fixable and the dev team does seem to be involved in discussion.Simply put, despite lots of apparent customizations, they fall absolutely flat. There is very little point to choosing a class as you can easily get the starting skills/gear of one class with minimal playing early in the game. The skill trees fall into 3 catagories: offense/defense/make money; there is no unique skill to be seen for skill development besides the ability to see what ores an asteroid will give you before you mine it, flying bigger ships, and I'll even count driving in reverse at an acceptable rate. It's true that there is some playstyle choices to be made here as to whether you focus on combat or money earning, but at the end of the day you'll still need combat skills in order to defend yourself, so there's no incentive to go for one specialization over another besides "I wonder if I can" (yes, you can, does it make any difference in the core gameplay? no.).While character customization is flat, ship customization is concave. Choose from 1 of 4 weapon types, make sure you skill up the ones you want so you can use them, then find the 1 or 2 ship frames with decent stats that allow you to use them. From there attach passive items to fit your playstyle, and get the biggest shield you can. The stats from ship to ship are woefully similar, 95% of the time you're going to care about only 1 thing: does the ship support the weapons I wanna use? Armor, hull plating, cargo space, manueverability etc are for the large part similar providing it's a ship in the same class. It's not so much "design your own ship" as it is "find the one with the right weapon slots and put stickers on it".The quests are the largest downfall for me here. Most of your time is going to be spent in autopilot taking object from station "A" to station "B", then report back to "A", or "go blow up this one bad guy and come back". There are a few exceptions, the fleet combat story missions are particularly noteworthy, and there is a cute quest about "hacking" which relies on actual programming knowledge to get through (non-required so no real penalties for failing, but refreshing to see a "click through" quest break the 4th wall in subtle way like this). The hopeful part is this: There are ways to improve customization using what is already in the game. Expanded skill trees, class-skills (even if passives like aforementioned mining skill), unique story options are all tools that could be used to diversify character development. Ship customization can be expanded upon with additional content. There are already a few interactive bits of ship design with modules like the EMP, more active and less passive options would make it feel much more unique. More and far more diversified ship frames will open up design space and has potential to actually allow players to make meaningful choices about the paths they will take in the game. Some of these fixes are already or will be made available through modding. But I can't in good faith recommend a game that needs mods to deliver on its promise. So, "No", for now.

												This game has everything I like in it. Spaceships, free exploration, trading, mining, missions, and an optional story. If you liked Privateer and always wanted a 2d version of Privateer, that's almost exactly what this game is. And that might be enough for some people. Unfortunately, the game is lacking polish in many respects. There are plenty of weapons, but aren't enough ships, engines, and shields to really create the kind of ship that will work well in the game. I think that the devs figured players would create these assets using mods, but the only mods out so far are cheaty ones. The economy is a bit off -- ships are a bit too cheap for what they are. There's no ties between resources being available and stations having more products or anything like that. Piloting needs some work. Colliding with NPCs is far too easy (in fact, it's the only maneuver some NPCs know). Most player ships can't turn fast enough or move their weapons fast enough to target NPCs without themselves striking NPCs. XP and leveling needs some work. Right now, the only way to level up quickly and easily is to shoot things. You can't level up easily by trading, hacking, or mining, except at the most basic levels. That might be because there are ways to break the system at later points in the game, but that just means that the system is weak and needs polish. There are distinct periods of boredom in between being able to do things in game. You finish the first couple of missions at level 3 or 4. You can't take on the next storyline mission until Level 10, and can't upgrade ships until Level 15. To get to level 15, you need to clear approximately two low-level systems of pirates. That's a lot of pew pew pew. And it's only reasonable to gain that XP by going pew pew pew, even if you classed as a miner or trader. I don't know right now if the game will age well and develop a following and some decent mods that will fix these problems. I haven't looked too closely at modding yet. There's a ton of promise here, but unless you're really grabbed by the story, there's very little good reason to play the game past the initial few hours.

												I can't really speak to multiplayer as I haven't gotten into it yet but my solo experience thus far has been a lot of fun.I started out as a fighter, I knew that combat was going to be prevalent no matter where I went so I wanted a little head start in that department. After taking a good look at the skill trees I decided that I actually wanted most if not all of them so throughout my playtime I have been carefully managing what I invest in next. The game can be a little grindy, especially if you've *chosen* to grind as I have, but it's always felt rewarding. Getting that next skill, being able to buy and then use that shiny new hull or weapon or ship upgrade is satisfying.A lot of zones unfortunately feel a little empty. Filled to the brim with pirates and aliens and in some cases more asteroids than you can mine in half a day, yes, but still empty as from a certain standpoint they're essentially just waypoints to your next stop. Hopefully in the (near) future we'll have more interactivity with these places if the game evolves to a point where we can actually claim and populate them. Extended main storylines to send you to more places would be great, too. All the same, if you're in need of exp or loot to sell it's easy to just pick a zone whose agression level is close to yours and have at it.Storywise it's pretty solid. You'll have access to a few missions to raise your rep with three of the factions before you actually join any of them. The main quest for the two I've seen are pretty short but well written and the difficulty in terms of how aggressive the zones you'll be visiting is pretty steep so your first playthrough with a new character will feel a lot longer as you level and gear up. There are also missions you can do for the commander at any station you visit. They're selected randomly from a preset list and it's totally up to you if you want to accept them or not. I found that fact to be irritating as I was only really interested in bounty and mining missions, thankfully loudent2 published a mod that allows you access to the whole list so you can just pick the one you want. Much more convenient and a must if you ever get frustrated at the random factor.There are a lot of items and upgrades to choose from at the beginning, which is awesome, but as you get into the higher levels (I was 146 at the time of writing this... yes I was lazy and copy/pasted my three day old forum post. Deal with it :P) you'll find yourself invariably with the same set of gear as most people; primarily speaking a dark matter generator, a dimensional fuel tank, and either a Hammer or a Death Bringer hull. And lasers. Lots of love for the lasers :).This is where modding really adds more life to it all. Last week I wanted a (much) shorter range laser that did more damage, I made one. It uses way too much energy imo but I made it, I use it, and so do a few other people now that it's on the Workshop. Then I wanted a rapid fire ballistic weapon that shoots fireballs, made that too. It's a little OP for anything under aggression level 70 or so but it's fun all the same. Got tired of shields, made new armor plating. So my modding skills are amateurish at best but more importantly I'm having a good time doing it, even learned a thing or two about XML along the way. Taking that into consideration, there are a lot of other people writing fantastic mods for the game and publishing them fairly regularly, it's been just over two weeks and there are 50 items in the Workshop already (albeit some of them are translations and don't really affect the core gameplay but I imagine they took a LOT of work and it's quite appreciated to a lot of players). It feels like there's always some cool new user made content to check out and maybe take for a spin. Maybe even share a few of your own ;).All in all it's a great game. Simple yet very well written, looks fantastic, controls are solid, great support and frequent updates. It has a lot to offer both in terms of content and expandability and it's a lot of fun, right to the point where I started playing one morning and actually forgot to eat anything until mid afternoon. Definitely worth the pricepoint.Can I click yes twice?

VoidExpanse is a top down open world space sandbox game. You play as someone from the Far Colonies who flees from a farm world on a civilian spacecraft, but who that character really is, is up to you. The plot of the game relies on the fact that the Far Colonies are abandoned, after a hostile alien race is discovered. Therefore, it is up to you to fight this threat, if you choose to do so that is. One thing that surprised was the fact that even though this is a simple, yet good looking 2D game, ti has a very detailed video options menu and separate audio sliders, which is a big plus in my book.Intro:Before being thrown into the procedurally generated universe of VoidExpanse you’re able to create your own character. The game offers a good variety of options such as, hairstyles, accessories and other facial characteristics to customize your character portrait You also have the option to choose one of 9 different classes such as Prospector, Trader, Rogue and Adventurer, each one having their own unique starting bonuses and preassigned skills.Upon entering the game, if you go on the Character tab you can see your character experience points and skills. Here, you can also access the following categories: piloting, combat, social, industry and engeneering. Each one of these categories has its own unique skill tree which is also affected by the profession you choose during your character creation. That said, I’d recommend you to take your time and examine these and determine which kind of role you want to play. You can be a pirate, a trader, a miner, how you embrance this open universe is entirely up to you. Different skills will have very different applications, some will allow you to persuade certain characters and avoid conflict, others will improve your piloting and mining skills, while others are just required in order to use better gear.Right next to Character tab, you also have the System Map which is very easy to navigate. It allows you to see the various planets on your current system, asteroids, enemies, space stations as well as jumpgates. It also allows you to set your own navigation points which you can use as destinations for your autopilot. Beware though, your autopilot isn’t smarth enough to avoid pirates and other dangers so make sure you’re actually paying attention to the game while you’re taking advantage of this very helpful feature.Next up, if you go on the Star System Map, you can see different systems connected by jumpgates and also see each factions territory. If you go to the Factions tab you can see what kind of relations each faction has with one another. There are a total of 6 different factions, including the neutral faction. Each one of these systems has their own characteristics and some might have special events such as gas clouds or debris from past conflicts. Here you can also see each system tech and danger level. The higher the tech level of a system, the better items you can find there and the danger level of a system will affect how difficult are the enemies there.Of course, as with any space sandbox game, you also have your lovely inventory. Here you can check what items you currently have and see what different modules you have equiped. Still, the only items that you can equip outside a space station are consumables, such as mines and repair kits. Modules such as an engine, generator and shield require you to be inside a space station. It is also on the inventory window that you can check your cargo, this is where you’ll hold various types of goods such as ores and food.Once you enter a space station you’ll be able to refuel, repair and check various sections of the station. On the hangar you can change your ship parts and on the shop you can buy and sell items. The type of items that are for sale on the shop vary depending on the type of station you’re in. If you’re on a military station you’ll get access to more military gear and if you’re in an outpost you’ll get access to more ships. However, the type of items you’ll find in these shops also depends on the Tech level of the system. Finally, you can also go to the station decks. Here you’ll find people from various factions and their reactions towards you will depend on your reputation with that faction. Most importantly, you can take missions and talk with them. You can ask them about the various different factions, about events and locations, thus gaining some background information on the events that are taking place or that previously took place.If you pick up a quest you can check it on your Journal. Here you can also see failed and completed quests. Any progress made within a certain quest will also be shown here as well as the dialogue and story behind it.Gameplay:The overall gameplay is really fun. You move your ship with W, A, S, D, Q and E and you aim with your mouse. Combat is in real time and hip movement and maneuverability is really important here, because weapons on ships have an arc of fire and so, you should try to keep yourself out of the enemy range. This allows for some sort of agile combat that requires you to keep both your ship moving and your weapons aimed towards the opponent at the same time.Flying around on your spaceship and fighting enemies requires you to keep an eye on some key things. Your ship has several meters such as energy, shield and structure, as well as fuel which is pretty self-explanatory. The shield bar obviously represents what percentage of shield you currently have on your ship, if this reaches 0 you’ll start taking structural damage and if you manage to not get hit during a certain time, your shield will eventually recharge. The energy meter on the other hand acts as if it is your stamina bar. Firing weapons and mining, for example, uses energy so you can’t just spam your weapons and have to time your shots correctly. That said, you’re also required to be at a full stop when mining, and the same goes for when you’re looting a container dropped by an enemy.Combat and movement aside, the game pretty much plays as you want to play it. You can attack friendly vessels, you can hunt down pirates or any other faction or you can just make your fortune by mining asteroids and selling the ore at a nearby space station. You can help characters and join a faction and help them achieve their ultimate goal, or you can just ignore everyone and just do your own thing. Verdict:Open sandbox world, choose how to play your own game. e.g. be a pacifist or a soldierNice looking visuals with 3D effectsTons of ship customizationMod supportFun combatChill musicDead multiplayerI HIGHLY recommend this game to fans of spacefaring, space sandbox and space sims. If you enjoyed games like SPAZ or Space Rangers I’m sure you’ll have a great time with VoidExpanse!

So that one day they can grow up to be the first man to discover an Alien race, and then nail it!!!!Well that escalated quickly, lets try to forget what I wrote... oh what?  you can't forget it..  That's fine, lets put it in a box, lock it and throw away the key..  here goes my review for VoidExpanse.   I have to say that personally I loved VoidExpanse, a open world space exploration sandbox game.  If you want to be a billionaire miner...  dust off that monocle, if you want to be a pirate hunter, than arg matey, have at it.  If you want to fight off the hostile aliens Independence day style, get that cigar out and be ready to smoke it...   You have so many options available to, you can mold and shift the game to suit your desires or ambitions.  The only limitations will be the ones in your mind. Gameplay The game is a top down shooter, you can move your ship using the W,A,S,D, or you can use the arrows keys, nothing too uncommon with that.  ProTip - use Spacebar to bring your ship to a complete stop, very useful for trying to pull in containers, mine asteroids  or port with the various space stations.  The combat is a combination of frustration and exhilaration, you'll be frustrated as the limitations of the game's combat system and the gliding nature of your ship, it can take quite a bit of getting used to before you master.   The exhilaration will come when you finally master combat, blowing up every enemy pirate ship or base you come across.   The rest of the game play is pretty straight forward, mine asteroids for ores, loot containers from ships you've destroyed or that have been destroyed by others.   Questing, experience, and levels, you can acquire quests while docked in a space station, numerous quest exist, delivery, rescue, destroy, etc etc etc.  These quest will grant you experience, although quests aren't the only way to get experience, you'll get it from just about every action in the game, from mining ore, to fighting ships, you even get experience for selling certain ores.   The experience is used to level up, each level will grant you points, which you can use on skills..  Skills are the life blood of your character, they allow you to shape and alter how you'll play the game.   Many different skill combinations exist, it's best to thoroughly inspect and decide what skills best fit your play style, loads of different combinations exist, will you be a smooth talker who gets his way with non violence, or will you decide to let your lasers, missiles or chain guns do the talking for you, the possibilities are endless.  Going right along with skill customization will be your ship, you can outfit your ship with numerous different parts, want to travel further without having to return for fuel... buy yourself a new fuel tank, want to mine more ore before having to return to port and sell... get  yourself a bigger hull.  Feeling tired of getting picked on and assaulted by pirate ships.. upgrade those weapon systems and wreck pirates.  So many combinations of ship parts exist, from your lowly civilian parts to high tech military grade items.  What kind of ship will you build? Pro's Huge galaxy to exploreLots of customization optionslimitless ways to play the gamehours upon hours of gameplay Con's Game is kind of empty (although this is outer space)Combat is kind of frustrating Recommendation I'd highly recommend this game, it's loads of fun, a great big universe to explore, many quest to complete, and so many different ship and skill combinations to try out.   I'd suggest buying it now, why wait, you have a very large universe to explore..

VoidExpanse is a hybrid sort of RPG/Strategy with bits of Simulation mixed in that takes place in a sci-fi space environment.  The level of different options available right from the start would qualify it as a sort of open world or sandbox style even, on a fringe sort of level, but nonetheless it certainly would qualify as such.ProsI've had a lot of fun leveling up.  The skills seem very worthwhile to get, and it's hard to decide on what I would like to work on next.  Level requirements of future upgrades can help in determining the order I want to go in though.I love the way the star systems are put together.  The combat is fairly easy so far, which I like.  Once I got some levels up, and better customized my ships.  Took time to get used to the ships too, but I am now able to use them fairly well, out of what I've tried thusfar.I enjoy the graphics and the music is nice as well.  I find it relaxing, and it doesn't get on my nerves like some games can tend to do after playing a while.Exploration has been a good thing too.  I'm still unsure how to progress, and which quests are more important for moving the story along.  They do seem to have symbols next to them in the journal.  Some of the "filler" quests are obvious, but they are good for the money and experience as well.  ConsI would like a little bit more variety as far as weapons and ship selection.  Maybe more can come about in the future?  There might be more I haven't seen yet as well.I think there are not enough types of quests.  You start to see the same "filler" ones appear again and again as you visit various star systems and base planets.I wish I were able to keep track of where things were in my storage areas in different star systems.  It's something I've had a difficult time retracing, especially in a medium to large sized system.I have seen a couple of small grammatical errors already, but they aren't too glaring, or anything so bad I cannot easily interpret what is being said, so I will sort of give a pass in that case.  Doesn't destroy the flow of the game, and I know I make my own from time to time, so not a huge deal.  I did notice a couple though.I'd definitely rather have several saves to utilize, and not a single one that autosaves often.  I like going back and trying different things, so having a single save per game is sort of a killjoy for me, personally.Early gameplay, and Other ThoughtsSo, I started my first game as a prospector, and got a few missions at the base it starts you at.  I destroyed a ship and got some crates, and I was pretty happy about that!  I venture a little further out, and I see several red marks on my radar, so I figure I would investigate.  Not Smart! I was toasted pretty quickly, so I lost some stuff, which was a letdown, but I had it on normal, as I wanted to get used to the basics of the game, so not a huge deal...  Just had to pay some money to get my ship back in working order, and off I went again on a different mission.  Luckily, this one was a straight shot with nothing in the way, and I finished it with no problems.  Level up!  Picked my traits, then while choosing what I wanted to level, I noticed I had some nice skills in my tree for mining...  So of course, the idea popped in my head, and I got a little tool in the shop to mine stuff from the asteroids, and started doing that.  Was getting decent experience from going out and back again, but I didn't  have much cargo room.  Still the experience plus the profit was a nice little side job to work on getting better parts, and so that became my focus for a little bit.  I'm glad there are different options like this for somebody to do based on where they are strong or weak after starting attributes.  A little over ten hours in now, and I've had a lot of fun leveling up so far, and the selection of various skills has really augmented my gameplay experience.  Some are pretty important, and others are more related to ones playstyle.  I don't sense a hard cap for level, but maybe there is at some point.  So far it's not very tough to level.  I wish there were more variety in what you can buy, and the variety of random filler quests could use a little bit extra quests, instead of running into many similar quests that you quickly begin to recognize.  I've run into the same ones many times, and I'd like to see more down the road.Despite having more cons than pros, the strength of the pros, and also the fact that I grouped some of the pros into multiple parts gives them an edge.  I am really enjoying this game!  I will probably continue on as neutral, and see where that takes me.  Maybe that has something to do with why I cannot figure out how to move along with the story.  Anyway, so far I highly recommend the game.  I enjoy the RPG system, and the other elements work well in conjunction with the overall gameplay experience.** Disclaimer:  I was given a key to review the game.  This had no impact on my rating**

												Ah, Space... it seems like space games are having a whole new renaissance these days. VoidExpanse is one of those games that sounds very simple, and even looks very simple. So, you start up a new game, and start mucking about, and then realize what feels like half an hour later that you've somehow lost several hours. The skill trees, the different ship hulls that actually FEEL like different ships, instead of just looking like them, and the fun of the combat... I'll be blunt: This game isn't a shiny polished AAA title. It has some quirks, particularly in the dialogue. However, VoidExpanse gets it right where it actually counts: It's fun to play, and the developers have a love for the game and community that shows in their continuing efforts to constantly improve and even expand the game. Lurler and co at Atomic Torch have built not just an excellent 2D space sandbox, they've built a devoted community, and the beginning of a reputation as a stand-up group of talented developers that actually care about their fans. Putting the developer and community aside, though, let me explain the game, since that's what's actually being reviewed. Firstly, you won't play the same exact game twice, even if the main story(ies) don't radically change. VoidExpanse is a 2D space sandbox kind of game in the vein of Space Rangers, Solar Winds, or (to a lesser degree) S.P.A.Z. You start off customizing you character portrait with a number of options (which can be expanded via workshop), pick a trade/class which will allot your starting skills, and then start off in a low-tech backwater space base. The game has a pretty low learning curve, and piloting your ship will become natural very quickly.There are two primary things that will determine your playstyle: 1) your skills, which will establish everything from what kinds of ship hulls you can pilot, how well you can pilot them, what kinds of weapons you can use, how well you can use those weapons, the types of trade and dialogue options available, what types of equipment you can use, and how efficient everything from mining lasers to fuel are. 2) your ship hull, which will determine cargo capacity, speed, maneuvering, and types of weapon mounts.You can spend your time just following the main story, and only doing odd jobs, trading, or mining as needed to upgrade your equipment as needed, or you can bum about as a space miner and make your fortune hunting rare ores to sell to the highest bidder. You can establish trade routes, become a bounty hunter... it's up to you. Granted, the actual variety of missions can be limited, but there are a few standout side missions that are truly unique. If you like the idea of a 2D space sandbox, they don't get much better than this. It has some flaws, but it delivers a solid and engaging experience, and is just loads of fun to play.Oh yeah... and you can play online. Just saying.8/10

												Overall: Hesitant dislike.  Kinda fun, kinda meh, lots of grinding, very empty; overall lands on the negative end, if only barely.It's a somewhat fun game, but spread too thin.  In the end I had some fun, but many game sessions felt unwholesome because of all the padding and time-wasting that diluted the experience.  It's also begging for content, so I'd recommend checking out lots of mods to enrich the experience; I now regret playing the game in its original form.TL;DR: It's kinda fun, but a very thin and grindy experience.  If you're looking for a time waster, it'll be fine for that; if not, it will feel very frustratingly slow and underwhelming.  I still feel an awful, kinda gross, unsatisfied sensation, even after beating it.  Like the time was very poorly spent.  :(  So keep that in mind when considering a purchase!There's very little story, and very few actual missions beyond the random ones the base leaders give you (and those are insubstantial).  Most of your time is spent traveling, whether on unsatisfying fetch or delivery quests, or traveling across half the galaxy to reach your quest again after a death.  The last few quests I did had a ton of travel from one corner of the galaxy to the other; very boring, even in the alien areas where the enemies were actually dangerous.  I did a medium sized galaxy and I recommend you try a small, simply to drop that travel time padding.Combat is somewhat fun, but it does feel awkward.  You're fighting foes who have the computer's good aim, but you need to aim manually and this makes many of the weapons awkward and impractical to use.  You need to figure out how to move with your weapon to land even a fraction of the hits, and enemies don't appear to be limited in ammo like you are.  I also figured out early on that energy weapons are the way to go -- instead of a limit of 20 shots, you turn your entire fuel tank into ammo, and you just need a powerful generator to keep your energy levels stocked.  If I remember right, for solid ammo, the game is extremely stingy with refill items for some reason, so you'll have to return to base constantly to stock up again; this is bad for longer missions, mining ventures, etc.The skill tree is almost entirely made of tiny stat upgrades, making you turn or strafe or cruise slightly faster, or do slightly more damage with a weapon type.  A few skills unlock better equipment, and one skill (persuade) adds dialog options in quests, and the rest are tiny, incremental stat boosts; very sterile.  For that reason the skill tree feels very unexciting... yes you make your ship work better, but with my level in the 60s it was only about 25-50% better in a select few areas.  And I had to focus in those areas to do it.  The game begs for that tree to be stuffed with new abilities in combat, mining, and quests, differences in *kind* instead of just differences in scale.Also it's a little frustrating that the starting classes are not even -- some simply have way more free skill points assigned at the start of the game.  You should play the class that has the most skills you like, but also the most skills total that you plan on taking... and that means doing some google searching.That's one example of how the game feels like it lacks balance, polish, and content.Did I enjoy it?  Yea, it was okay.  But man was it a slow grind, and I feel like a different game might have done a better job.  I walked away from this game multiple times because I felt crappy after playing it, because the experience had been so grindy and empty.  It's an awful feeling.What's impressive is the good parts were just good enough to leave me nostalgic, and I returned to finish the story.  It actually feels like they were planning a bigger game, ran out of time/budget, released what they had with plans for later expansions, but then had to abandon it when the negative reviews rolled in. 												An interesting 2d top down space sandbox with elements resembling single ship space pirates and zombies, Eve, and a little system shock 2, replete with that new-car indie smell.You generate a galaxy, pick what class's skill package you want to start with, and are dropped in the starting system and offered a tutorial. There are a variety of ship types and weapon types to choose from, various techs to find, and a number of factions of varying difficulty to join.How you gain experience and money is up to you; You can visit stations and talk to npcs to try and get odd jobs,go around hacking old alien ruins floating around for stuff to sell/turn in for science points,go around fragging pirates randomly,trading goods between stations,or hunting down valuable resources hidden in asteroids.The combat has been harkened in other reviews to be like "Ice skating motorcycle duels" and that's KINDA true. It's more remenicent of 2d top down naval battles, where each of your weapons have their own arcs and you have a radar you can use to fight things off screen with guided weaponry, and you're sliding along space trying to avoid getting shot up too hard. It's ok.My only gripe is that it's easy to get in over your head, and dying isn't the end, and the game is very grindy.See, the game constantly autosaves, and you aren't allowed to make your own saves. The game is effectively ironman, so if you die then you die. You get deducted a small amount of money and are respawned inside the nearest friendly station. This may sound like a good thing, except for your super expensive investiture of a ship being completely gone for good as well as its contents. You have to buy up the (thankfully free) civilian junk and start from scratch. It's a lot like EVE in this way.Which has the major downside of runing into the grind wall that the game seems to be.  You get such a small trickle of money for the effort that you put into the game that it often is faster to just start a new galaxy and start from scratch rather than grind from a civ ship back up to where you died. There's also a few interesting mods on the workshop, most are russian with (mostly) english translation.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
Introduction:VoidExpanse is a Top-Down, Open World Space RPG with a branching story line. With the ability to define how big your universe may grow, this game can take you quite some time to fully explore. As an added bonus, since the universe is procedurally generated, you will never experience the same universe twice in a row. The game has a beautiful backdrop which can make each system look and feel somewhat unique. The character portraits being randomized for non-key NPCs also add a refreshing new feel to each replay of the game. The ships have enough detail and varietie for this style of art to make them visually appealing as well. The sounds are fairly standard, but they work fine for this game.Gameplay:There are many different character options to choose from at the start of the game. You customize your character portrait as well as your starting Class. Starting Classes just give you a head start down their related Skill Trees, however as you play, it is completely feasible that you could max out every Skill Tree.Skill trees are the games way of locking you out of content that would otherwise make you too powerful to start with. Luckily, early on it is easy to gain levels so you can quickly unlock better ships and weapons that you may need to progress. This system does have a bit of a drawback though. When playing through one of the factions, I was told I had to destroy enemy space stations using a custom missile that I was issued. This is where a major issue occurred for me. Since this was my second play through, I had opted to play as a miner/trader who operated a freighter. My freighter was only a middle tier ship that had medium pulse lasers. My ship wasn’t designed to fight and didn’t even have a bay that could support a missile let alone a level 3 one. It was simply equipped to defend against a single attacker or a few lower class attackers while making its escape. I had almost maxed out my energy weapons, Industry (mining), Social (trade skills) and my Piloting (to enhance cargo space and speed) skills. This meant I had not focused anything on the other weapon types or heavier hulls. I had bought myself a very heavy beam only Death Bringer ship for making runs into the Alien space and the heavy pulse weapons for it… but didn’t have the skills to fly it yet, was still working on that. At this point I knew I was either screwed or I was in for one heavy grind. I needed to be able to get enough skill points to unlock level 3 Missiles, heavier hulls and the money to buy the ship and everything I needed to equip it properly. I had to do tedious filler missions given by the random stations while doing mining runs to raise the experience and money required. Days later, I finally had my heavy ship loaded to the teeth with everything including my missile. This made blowing up those Alien space stations even more satisfying because of the effort I had to put in to it. As mentioned, there are plenty of customization options for this game. There are quite a few different ships to choose from, each with its own loadout slots and statistics. It would be nice if there were a few omni-slot ships that let you customize it exactly how you want, but using the ones already in game works. There is an even wider assortment of weapons to choose from plus the critical ship systems and subsystems that can also be customized. The numbers of configurations you can make are almost limitless. This, along with the aforementioned procedural generation of the selectable size universe helps to make each replay unique. One feature I like is the fact that your character isn’t a miracle worker. If you find yourself a better weapon floating in the debris of the ship you just vaporized, you can’t just slap it on to your ship and fly off merrily on your way. You have to get to a space station and dock with it in order to adjust critical components of your ship. Really the only thing your pilot can do while out and about is to reload the consumable things such as hull repair or shield energy. This is a rather good decision on the Developers part as it adds realism to the game. It actually makes it a little more exciting to know that if you don’t survive the trip back to the nearest space station, your new found prize will be lost when you explode. Why might you want to replay the game? Well after the introductory area, there are three factions all looking to take you in as a recruit. Once you determine which faction you want to join you can seek out their recruitment officer. The recruitment officer of course doesn’t let just anyone join, you must prove yourself worthy of their cause. This is where the story lines diverge. Once you are in a faction you will have to stick with that choice until the end of the game. The end mission will be changed to suit the faction you are a member of, be it to blow the aliens out of their part of the galaxy, find a way back home, or finding a way to pacify alien hostility. Unfortunately, once you finish the starting area and do all the efforts required to join a faction, when you are really ready to get going, the game hits the home stretch and ends shortly after. This game relies on the fact you have to do the generic missions, hunt enemy (or if you are a jerk, friendly ships) and mine in order to gain experience and money. This works great early on but becomes a very heavy and barely rewarding grind in the later portion of the game. The deeper into the Alien territories you go, the heavier their resistance becomes. You will quickly find yourself swarmed with ships at a far higher level than you. Another issue I had is if you take a jump gate then look at your map too long, you will find a swarm of pirates zoning in behind you and almost killing you before you can move. Death is also unforgiving and what it takes from you is based on what difficulty setting you took at the beginning of the game when generating your universe.Another thing that pads out gameplay is travel time. Often you will find the mission provider and the mission system are separated by a vast distance. You then need to fly there with the assistance of Jump gates to link systems together… but unfortunately there is not usually a direct route. You will have to pass through each system that separates you and your destination dealing with any hostiles that may decide to attack you. You also need to watch your fuel levels or you will find yourself having to limp home at a low speed. Overall, there is plenty to do in VoidExpanse. It is a fun enough game that you might find yourself replaying it just to see how the story ends for each of the factions. Pro:Highly customizable ships, equipment, and weaponsProcedurally Generated Universe so it is different each time you playMultiple Factions helps enhance replayabilityPlay it how you want for the most part. Be a trader, a miner, a bounty hunter, a pirate or any combination of the above Cons:Must do introductory level each time you do a fresh restartA lot of grinding is required to survive late gameRepetitive filler quests used solely to help you level up and gain money. You find the same few quest types no matter where you go. Kill this pirate, rescue this crew, or deliver this cargoA lot of flying around between systems to get from point A to B then back to A again. Very time consuming and gets old. Would be nice if you could just radio in that you finished the mission rather than flying half way across the galaxy again just to turn it inAble to spend skill points in such a way it can mess you over later in the game. It’s fixable but you will need to grind to do it

												This game is very addictive. Seems a little simplistic and the controls take a bit of getting used to. I crashed quite a bit until I got the hang of it down and I still am not very good at shooting down ships without a lot of misses but I have been really addicted to this game since I started playing it. Your a space ship captain and you fly around different sectors completing jobs, mining materials, and fighting bad guys to make money and upgrade your ship. There is a story line but to be honest I really haven't been paying much attention to it as I've been more focused on getting new ships and the best equipment for them. I've almost gotten the heavy cruisers, which is the heaviest ship in the game unlocked and I'm excited for it. I've found that mining is the easiest and safest way to make money and is almost always necessary as fuel to fly costs money so you can't just go from station to station without either fighting or mining to keep at least enough money to fuel your ship. Fuel is expensive so I recommend upgrading your mining equipment quickly so you can get the best materials so you an offset costs quickly so you have more money for upgrades. I definitely want to note that the developer is very active with this game. I happen to have started playing the day they released a patch that broke the game. I was stuck in the starting system and couldn't complete the tutorial to leave. They had the issue resolved in less than a day so while it wasn't the best experience, at least they are active and pay attention when issues arise. I haven't played multiplayer and probably won't as I'm more into the single player experience so I have no recommendations on how that works out but I bet it would be a pretty good time. I definitely recommend this game if you are interested in a game where you are given a ship and almost free reign to make your fortune and get the most powerful equipment you can. Only negative I can think of that I ran into other than the update issue is that sometimes you have to end up with issues because the game is so intense in regards to fuel. I ran into a few times where I got stranded because a few systems in a row didn't have any place to refuel. Recommend you keep some power cells handy just in case. Some people may also find some issues with the slow pace of mining as well. Each instance takes about 5 seconds and you are just sitting there. Doesn't seem like much but when you only get 60 pieces every time you mine, it can get tedius to fill a ship with a big cargo hold.... this is especially prevailent when you are going for a specific ore for a mission and are only getting 2 to 4 each time and you need 350 to complete the mission. Definitely a great game though and I recommend it for anyone that likes space ship games. Definitely not X2 as far as economy goes but its still a great game.

												Sandbox-esque space combatTop down space combat has been done before, lets get that out of the way.  From some of my earliest video game memories playing Star Control till recently with S.P.A.Z. this game follows a familiar combat formula.  But that's not a bad thing in any way.  Strafe, steer, and blast your way through your enemies with a bunch of changeable loadouts, ships, and different classes of 'hulls'  (the skeleton for the ship you'll use).  What makes this game great is the sandbox element.  It doesn't tell you what to do, but it does have branching quests.  Of course you're free to completely ignore them and just while away the hours mining asteroids if you so chooose.  Go to war with one of the factions in the game, or try to eliminate the alien menace that dominates a large chunk of the galaxy.  Ultimately it's up to you.If there's one big complaint about the game it's that it feels a little empty.  You hit a wall around your late 30s where the experience points seem to take a lot longer and the upgrades are much further apart then you'd like.  With some of them being only say, a 3% to your cruising speed, leveling feels pretty underwhelming after a while.  Thankfully you get experience for doing pretty much anything in this game.  Also combatting the emptiness is the modding community which already has full game overhauls, rebalanced skill trees, new hulls, new weapons, new quests, and more.  I'd like to see even more modding for this game personally, as more content can only improve an already great game.If you like this style of game, it's well worth the purchase price.

												YES! This is what I was looking for! Open sandbox space sim where you choose your own path! Oh man I don't even know where to start, so I'll give a summary of my playthrough so far:I fired it up, set it to normal and rand-gen'd some bloke to play as (ended up with a guy with a pink mohawk and a hawaiian shirt. The absurdity has grown on me a bit). And I hit it right off. The interface and controls weren't too intuitive, but not too cryptic either. I had it pretty well figured out in under 5 minutes, and started working for the tutorial guy. And he taught me asteriod mining and mission running and trading and some basic combat and and then gave me a run down of what's going on in the sector then it was a pat on the butt and off you go. That's it. You get to kick it into high drive within.. 30 minutes? Of the game start. And the depth of the game is great. There's 5 factions, only one of which I know well, one I have a good idea of, and one that's a mystery to me, one's pirates and the last one is the EVIL ALIENS (TM). You level up and allocate your XP points to your skills, which go all the way from asteriod mining up to PEW PEW BANG and everything inbetween. And I mean everything. There's some really weird skills in there. Combat can leap between fairly routine to very surprising, depending on how high you keep your guard up. I was doing pretty damn well off the start beating up pirates and mining rocks, so I got pretty full of myself and headed into a fairly dangerous system to rack up some XP.Ha ha they beat my♥♥♥♥♥like a drum. I needed a bigger ship.Now, ship size isn't terribly noticable. I suppose because they'd have to zoom the screen out a lot to make a difference. It's basically just better hull, and better weapon placement. Which is a huge thing in combat. It's not so much the size of your gun, but whether or not you can bring it to bear! Some turrets point forwards, to the sides, out the back, etc! And also you have to match them up to their type of weapon. Energy/Kinetic/Missile/Mine. So, each ship has its own style of combat.Ship equipment is fairly straightforward. You want bigger and better, but you need to carefully manage how much fuel and power your fuel tank and reactor can provide. The thing I like is the fact you don't need to strip old ships for parts. No, your hull is literally just another equipment slot. You just swap it out and bang, new hull same equipment. Very enjoyable and challanging at times. It's going to see hundreds of hours from me.

												Word to the wise  - Autopilot is a little drunk at times.I'll admit the game feels very early access at times, with the amount of crashes and updates that have happened in the last few days, not just patching bugs, but dealing with content and balance issues.  Basically you are put in charge of a single ship of which can be minorly upgraded through various slots of boosters/weapons/otherwise.  There are a good deal of ships, all specializing in some area so it becomes a game of deciding what your play style is and attempting to find the right weapons/ships/addons to facilitate that. I'd started off a few times as an Adventurer, and found my focus exceedingly split between all the different avenues one can pursue.  Eventually I settled upon Prospector and that I feel gave me a solid base to build from (As it nearly maxes out the Mining Tree).  It doesn't though, seem to matter what class you pick as it throws you down the same funnel as everyone else - and nobody seems to comment or the game adjust itself for your choice outside of the points spent on builds.Factions are seemingly a big deal,  but having given a cursery look at what was to offer nothing really struck me as a place that is beneficial for someone who just wants to shoot lasers at rocks and collect things.  (There is no, straight up miners guild or anything - and of course you start out with almost maxed stats in that so in there isn't much further progression outside of spending into survivability) There are quiet a few space stations somewhat randomly laid out dependent upon your specific world seed.  Within these places you can gather quests which fall under the basic structures "Go get this" "Go kill this" "Make sure this doesn't get killed" "Talk to this person" "Deliver this" They don't seem to particularly care who you are as it just appears randomly when you ask the station commander (Sorta wish there was a job board instead)Outside of that, there is a story that you are trying to progress, and the day to day dealings of being within a space sand box . Of which, there are limited resources and enemies in certain areas, so in, you could go on a mission in faction controlled sections and wipe out every last dirty space pirate you come across.   I do find myself wishing there was the ability to do more with friendly NPC's (As basically you can only ask them the usual questions or attempt to buy fuel off them if you happen to be low). My limited experience with multiplayer has left me a little skepitcal on that front.  As you start out as a new player in every game you enter (No carrying a ship and progress over from place to place) You are basically at the mercy of a star system that very well might be almost completely devoid of enemies or I imagine ore to mine (As stated before, things can be limited).  The place I was in, I was hard pressed to find anyone in any of the faction sections, and the non-faction sections of space were basically slim pickings.Also, it should be known that if someone takes their game offline you lose that character and whatever progress/stuff you've accumilated. So in, seemingly less reason to tread in those waters but to hang out with friends and futz around. I've still been enjoying my time with the game so far - and while I'm not sure if they have loftier plans for the games future, though from what I've been able to gleam, they seem intent upon adding more (How much, only they, and I imagine the funds gotten from selling the game will decide).

												This game might not be perfect, but it certainly is an overlooked gem. I have a somewhat strange fascination with rogue-likes/lites. I also quite enjoy a nice space exploration game. I quite like this game and I keep coming back. Not all games get the formula right, but I think this one does. Some people might say that this game is too easy. I wouldln't know, I find it just right. I am playing it on Normal difficulty though so your mileage may vary. Graphically, it looks decent enough. It's 3D models and particle effects are quite beautiful with lovely backdrops. I would say though that perhaps the backdrops are a bit too colourful. Most of space is empty and black, and I find it hard to believe that you'd see this other huge galaxy in the distance. Sure it would still be millions of light years away, but isn't very realistic. That isn't to say that I don't appreciate them, I do. It makes it seem a bit less bleak than space normally would be.The music holds up, and gives your ears something to listen to although I didn't much care for the music at the start screen. I like the sound design. Although, the ships don't actually have that much difference in engines and the various other effects are the same if you have a Level 1 or Level 3 Laser.In my current run, I find that Laser Energy weapons are by far the best and easiest to aim. A lot of it comes down to the ship though. There are various types of those. I haven't tried Multiplayer yet, but when I do, I will be sure to comment on it.The story is the same, but the destinations are procedurally generated. There are various types of missions. Rescue, Mining, Delivering Packages, Intel, a few mini-games in hacking Enerak terminals. I discovered that running out of fuel wasn't the end of the world, but you travelled a lot slower, even whilst cruising. Without fuel, your ship is severely exposed and crippled. You have no energy for weapons or shields, but you can still live to fight another day.Is it a perfect game? No. I found a few glitches mostly to do with the autosaving message (it is a bit offscreen, I am playing at 4K. I also found that sometimes when you dock with the autopilot or not, the ship circles around the object a bit swirling closer and closer in and then eventually docking. Overally, I really like this game. There is something about exploring space, fighting pirates, mining, and buying parts for your ship to upgrade it. If you enjoy rogue-likes/-lites then you'll enjoy this.

												Great game for the 1st 20 hours or so. After that it becomes brutally hard (in an unbalanced manner, not in a hard-but-fun Dark Souls manner), and as some have noted the mid/end-game is lacking in content. In mid to end-game your RPG skills/ship progression comes to a crawl as difficulty ramps up very suddenly (too suddenly IMHO) while remaining repetitive (combat becomes harder but there's not anything really 'new' to it - compare this to S.P.A.Z. which introduces a whole new combat dynamic (the zombies) mid-game, which keeps things fresh.) Combat at level 5 feels much like combat when you're level 40, it's just much harder. So after a while the game starts to feel like a real grind. This game is like a cross between a prettier S.P.A.Z. and a more action-oriented Space Rangers 2, albeit in a 'light' form. It feels superior to S.P.A.Z.  for the first 10-20 hours because the basic combat mechanics work very well - I love using mines, and it's fun to find just the right weapon combo amongst a pretty good selection of weapons. However VoidExpanse runs out of steam at about level 35-40. Some of the quests are interesting but a most of them get very grindy/cliche/repetitive fast. Still, production values are higher than with SPAZ or Space Rangers 2, and combat is a lot of fun, at least for a while. If the developers put in more mid to end-game content, more high-end ship components, and did more balancing in mid/late game, and added more features like the ability to hire henchman (sometimes you're given a henchman, but it'd be great to hire and manage them at will) then this game would be AWESOME! As it is, like I said it's fun for the first 20 hours, so for $15 I got my money's worth and I give it a thumbs up.

												Man oh man where to begin. This game is a mishmash of so many great sci-fi titles I'm just going to hilight a few of the ones they took the best qualities from. First there's the combat which for oldschool guys will remind you of a modernized Starcontrol 2 melee battle right away with its newtonian physics and fast paced action. Then in 2002 there was this great little SHUMP called Starscape which I beleive to be the true spiritual successor to this title. Look it up on Steam and watch the trailer to know what I mean. It was a blend of the classic arcade game Sinistar that threw a touch of Wing Commander Privateer's exploration, commerce and ship upgrades into the mix. Now add in expansive multiplayer that can support up to 10,000 people per server, RPG dialogue, factions, character creation, player classes, and FTL's hypnotic space opera music score on top of all of that and you've got Void Expanse. You can focus on combat, mining, salvage, exploration, you name it. The learning curve is easy to pick up, controls extremely crisp and the multiplayer features allow for PvE and FFA PvP servers. There's even full steamworks and modding support.All in all despite the occasional crash/bug, this game is a total package and steal for the modest price tag.

												The game could use a little more content and polish, but it is worth the asking price. I've only run into 2 technical problems, a pathfinding bug which is very minor, and the occasional crash (irregular, sometimes it crashes at launch, other times I can play 4-8 hours without a problem).Game uses an Asteroids (for those who remember that game) style physics system, which means that when you head in a direction, you continue to drift. You will stop eventually, but not quickly enough to warrant changing this description. Personally, I've never been fond of this style, but that is a matter of preference and hopefully a moder will give us a choice on it.There are several tiers of ships and weapons, and there is a decent amount of customization. Ship selection isn't vast, but it is enough to have a comfortable amount of choice, and its highly moddable with ship hull mods being the most common at this point (yt-1300, and star trek mods already out). Weapon selection could also use a little more expansion as well, but again, its enough to give a decent amount of choice.There are multiple campaign routes to take, one for each faction except neutral. Optional quests are sparse, but cover the basics, trading, mining, escort, courier, and bounty (mod available to allow the player to choose which they take).Game could definitely be fleshed out more, and a lot of things are underway, but in its current condition, it is worth the asking price. It doesn't blow me away, but neither do I regret buying it.Game does not support gamepads, or any other control method besides mouse and keyboard at this time.Also, since this is an issue to some people, you will have to make an account for the game. Doing so consists of giving a username that is not already taken, and nothing more. This is done to make multiplayer run smoothly, but multiplayer is purely optional, creating a username, however, is not. No personal information is requested.

Then you can reward curious players that take the time to explore a system by hiding interesting things in it (and no, the alien relics that are only good for science points don't count. content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												VoidExpanse is an arcade version of Escape Velocity.  It's a much shallower world, with a larger focus on action.  Pirates/hostiles aren't an anomaly, they’re scattered across every map like koopas and goombas, they’ll jump into any fight even when they’re horribly outmatched.They have added XP for pilot leveling, and a skill tree to specialize your pilot, which is a nice improvement. Staying true to the more arcade feel, these rewards come fast and furious.  I’ve put in 5 hours (5 learning hours, so plenty of time reading tool tips and trying to figure things out) and am already level 35.The ship upgrade process is also streamlined.  The hull is just one more slotted upgrade (although it does change which weapon slots are available), and there’s no weight attribute to balance things out.  So you never need to decide how to optimize one ship, while saving for another, you just grab an upgrade for whichever slot you can.  Not a lot of decisions to make, you just get the next level of your radar/fuel tank/grappler, and if you happen to switch out hulls, they stay with you.  Like the pilot leveling, these upgrades come fast.  You never really reach the limits of your ship, and set a goal for a better ship, you’re just constantly upgrading everything before you hit the limit.  I don’t know that I need a new generator, but one’s offered, so you upgrade it. You don’t really have any sense of accomplishment.The factions are also very simplified.  There seem to be 6 total, and you're basically chosing between 2.  Pirates; Aliens that are trying to wipe out humanity; people that worship said aliens; neutrals; and then the two choices: Freedom or Order.  So far, it seems like progression of these quest lines are pretty much on rails.  Helping Order doesn’t seem to make Freedom like me any less.There’s a nice dialog system in game, where you can ask anyone about any topic you like.  While the system’s nice, it doesn’t seem to be very fleshed out.  Most everyone just repeats the tutorial for most options, and there doesn’t seem to be much of a reward for being thorough or going deep.Quests are fairly simplified, too.  There are bounty missions to kill one particular pirate in the system you’re in (and he’s marked on the radar).  You can do rescue missions to a piece of debris in your system.  Then there are escort missions and package deliveries, which go to different systems, but there’s no concept of time, so you can just pick up as many as you want and drop them off when you happen to get to the system. There’s a cargo quest I’ve been offered a couple times, but they warn you you need a lot of space (unspecified) so I’ve declined it.  The last generic quest I’ve been offered is a mining contract, which is always for the same amount of the same mineral.   Much like the dialog system, it seems like the quests really need to be fleshed out.In true arcade form, death is only a minor inconvenience.  Your body’s cloned (the cost is equivalent to about 1 quest reward) and your ship, it turns out, is fully insured. You lose your non-quest inventory, and that’s it.The ship to ship fighting has some interesting mechanics, different weapons having different tracking speeds, being able to assign different weapons to different firing groups.  I think it suffers for the camera being way too close.  If a ship comes in from the top of your screen, it’s already within range of your weapons, and is only ~8 ship lengths away. If things were zoomed out, so you could play with the edge of your weapons range, it opens up a lot more tactical dogfighting.To sum up, it’s Arcade Escape Velocity, for all the positives and negatives that “Arcade” brings with it. I’d appreciate a bit more depth at a more deliberate pace, but VoidExpanse really leans towards the arcade feel.  Hopefully they expand on the dialog tree and quest options as time goes on.  And maybe at later levels you’ll actually know you want/need an upgrade before you’ve already obtained it.  Last note: I’m playing on a 5k iMac and even after lowering the video options it gets choppy in cruise mode.  It also requires a monoframework package install, and I’ve had a few freezes.Holding out hope for improvements, but as is I can't recommend this game.

												 The game has some fun moments when you first start playing, however the MP experience which many enjoy is severely lacking.
